Long ago, in a wilderness near a village, the village had abundant trees, flowers, and fruits. Nearby there were two groups of monkeys, each with five hundred members, each with a monkey king.
One of the kings dreamed that five hundred monkeys threw the two kings into a hot cauldron.
In this dream, he was greatly startled and his body hair stood on end. He then woke up from the dream.

What I have seen in this dream is not good, is it?
We must abandon this place where we live and move to another place.'
The group of monkeys said:
'As the great king has said, we must run away.'
The Bodhisattva is of great authority and virtue, and if he sees a dream, it must be true.
The king then called the second king and said:

The king found it hard to believe and said:
'Is it possible to believe everything one dreams?
If you want to go, you can go as you please.
I have now obtained a wide territory here, and I will never leave.'
The king knew that it was hard to convince him, so he led his own group of five hundred monkeys to another place.
Later, in that village, there was an inferior maid roasting barley. A sheep came to the side of this maid to eat the barley.
The maid immediately lit a fire, burned wood, and hit the sheep. The fire caught on its body and it was burned severely. It ran into the king's elephant stable.

The Buddha told the monks:

Long ago, in a certain place, there was a rat king with five hundred rats as his retinue.

Having thought this, it looked around everywhere and saw that a mouse king lived in this place with five hundred mice as its retinue. It then went to the mouse hole and pretended to be sitting in meditation.

' Then, together with the mice, they circumambulated the old cat to the right, going around three times, and then entered the hole.

In the past, there were two guides, each with five hundred carts passing through the desert, some finding water and grass, some not finding water and grass, and after several days, the cows and calves suffered greatly.
